reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s main optimistic pathway in section 3 (partial AM-convergence plus trade/compromise), so it is moderately central; if trade reliably backfires, a large chunk of the essay’s optimism weakens, though the overall position also discusses other pathways and already flags threats as a key failure mode. The argument’s strength is limited because it mostly asserts a mechanism (moral trade sets prices that incentivize creating “suffering assets”) without engaging the essay’s own section 3.3 on threats, the possibility of anti-threat institutions, or why threat-creation would be larger than in non-cooperative power-grab scenarios; it reads more like an amplification of a conceded risk than a refutation. Correctness is moderate: the general incentive story is plausible and aligns with known extortion/threat dynamics, but it arguably mischaracterizes the paper as “advocating” institutionalized moral trade (the paper treats it as conditional and explicitly worries about threats), and the “likely far beyond” comparative claim is speculative. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Moral trade creates incentives to manufacture suffering as a bargaining asset
